South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.p: The "Allenburys" DIET is a complete milk and farinaceous Food, easy of assimilation, most agreeable to take, simply and quickly made. It is recommended in place of ordinary milk foods, gruel, etc., and whilst acceptable to all as a light nourishment, it is particularly helpful to Dyspeptics, Invalids and the Aged. In the sick-room it will be found invaluable and it is easily and quickly made, the addition of boiling water only being necessary.

The "Allenburys" DIET is readily digested by tose who are unable to take cow's milk and is particularly serviceable in convalescence. When taken as a light supper diet it will be found to promote tranquil and refreshing sleep. Although this DIET is a good for ADULTS and is entirely distinct fom the "Allenburys" Foods for Infants, yet it is also of great value as a restorative food for young children, especially during convalescence.
For Invalids, Dyspeptics & The aged.
Allen & Hanburys Ltd., Lombard St. London.

div.p: Between January Ist and January 16th 49,664 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 22,2*6 tons were Welsh. 7.529 Newesstle, 8,881 Yorkshire, 4,784 Scotob and 5,934 other qualities During the corres ponding period of last year the imports totalled 25,358.

div.head: Tramway Accident
div.p: Barly yesterday afternoon a (treek girl while attempting to mount a tram in motion near the Uianaclis station lost ber bold of the rail and fell backwards between the first and seoond class cars. The girl was terribly injured and died last night No blame could possibly be attached to the wattman or any servant ol the company, the accoulient being due entirely to the infringement of rules and veglect of personal safety so often apparent in such cases

div.head: DR: RUTHERFORD VISIT.
div.p: PRESENTATION OF ADDRESS.
Yesterday afternoon Dr. Rutherford M.P., attended a meeting of the Constitutional Reform, and was presented with the following address —

To Dr V. H Ratherford MP. One of the Secretaries of the Egyptian Parliamentary Jommittee. We, the undersigned, on behalf of the Constitutional Reform League have the honour to bid you welcome and tender to you onr most corlial thanks for your presence amongst us Words fail to convey our senti- ments of esteem and admiration fer yoo Bir. and your worthy colleagues in Parliament, for your strenvous and persistent exertions in vindicating our claims and redressing our
grievances

Egyptians without distinction of party, will never forget that it was throogh your untiring exertion that the British Government acceeded its consent to the exercise of Hie Highness the Khbedive's clemency in favour of the Densha wai prisoners. That was a triumph in the cause of homanity which yoo may look back upon with justifiable pride, and we doubt not that this conspicoous success wil! stimulate and evcourage our English friends iv endea- vouring to obtain for as our rights and in realizing our aspirations.
The natore of those rights and the character of those aspirations may best be gleaned from article II]. of our statutes wherein we set forth the objects of our organization. They are as icllows -—
(a) The maintenance of the Khedivial authority as guaranteed by the Pirmans conferring upon Egypt administrative independence.

Reliance upon the pledges giveo and declarations made by Great Britain at the time of the occapation with the claim for ther fulfilment A demand fr tative inetitutions invested with tull political and adminim trative powers in so far as Egyptians and Egyptian interests are coucerned. (d) Primary education to be general and turtoua. K rabie to be the mediam of instruction in all Egyptian Government schools. Posts in the Egyptian Government to be given to natives acourding to their capacity and merit with the object or diminishing as far as pos-ible the nomber of foreigners in the service of the Government and thos enabling the Kgyptians to learn to govern them sel ves Extension or the jurisdiction of the mixed Courts, wbich already try civil, commer vial, and petty offences, to criminal cases in which foreigners are concerned until euch period as it may be possible to inaugurate unity of junsddiction, and thus affirm the t principle of justice for all who inbabit the same country— namely, "equality" before the law."

We hope thatthe purposes for which this league has been formed and the methuds by which it will seek to achieve them may meet with your entire approbation. It is almost need leas to add that as we largely rely upon the powerfi! cooperation of the British Parliamen- tary Committee for the fulfillment of our desires
t will ever be our most sincere and earnest endeavonr to act in complete accord with them ainito thatend we shall at all times be grateful for their wise and experienced counsel

div.p: But since that time the whole aspect of mat ters has changed to our incalculable advapn- tages, and the Britixh Parhament no longer turns a deaf ear to Egypt's reasonable demanda, and it is due to the chivalrons championship of you, Sur, and the devoted band with which you are arsociated that we are at last enabled to make our voioes beard

For this, Egypt owes you a debt of gratitude wbich she can never adequately repay We ask you to beheve that every speech you make and every question you ask on our behalf is fol lowed in Eyypt with eager interest and evokes 'in every patriotic beart a feeling towards you of genuine devotion.

We are convinced that the resnits of your sojourn bere, which we wish could bave been prolonged, will be productive of antold bene fits to our country ; we ardently trust that you will carry away with you such pleasant me mories as will induce you ere long to revisit var beloved vountry, where you may ever count upon @ bearty reception ; and we earnestly beg you toconvey to our friends and supporters in the British lales the expression of our affeo- tion and regard

div.head: THE OASIS RATLWAY.
div.p: TO-DAY'S PROCEEDINGS.
(Prom Our Sprotat Comagsron peyt)
Kharga, Satorday

The programme for to-day has consisted in excursions to the various places of interest with which the Kharga Oasis abounds, the most noticeable of these being the ancient Christian Necropolis aod the Temple of Hibis. An iospection bas also been made of « portion of the lauds under the control of the Corpora. tion. aod the remarks made by the Chairman of the Company in the appended ¢peech as to the falsity of the statements which have been made denying the existence of either water or oultiv. able land in safficient quantities to make eul- tivation @ paying concern, will be tully ap preciated by all who were present here to-day There can be po doubt as to the agricultural possibilities of the Onsis. The soil is of wonder. fol richness and all samples obtained from the different sorta of crops which have been tried have yielded results which are well up to standard. At the conclusion of lunch this morning the Chairman, in proposing the health of his Highness the Khedive, tendered his thanks ov behalf of the Corporation to HE Pakbri Pasha for the important part which he had taken in yesterday's proceedings and for having accompanied the other guests to the Oasis. Fakbri Pasha responded in a few wel! chosen words, and expressed bis complete satis faction with all be had seen
Mr. Heaton-Armstrong, MP. spoke as fol lows: —

Some years ago it pleased bis Highness the Khedive and bis Government to grant me the concessions which are now owned and worked by the Corporation of Western Egypt. | will on behalf of myself and the founders make but a few remarks. | should like firstly to thank his Excellency for being bere this day and the per sonal interet he has shown in al! that be has seen Personally | am delighted to be here to commernorate ao important event in the histo ry of modern Egypt. The foonders of this en terprise supplied the Corporation with a large sum of money for working capital and have fulfilled all the conditions imposed upon them to the satisfaction of the Government The promise made years ago to the inhabitants of the Oasis by Johnson Pasha bas been fulfilled and its effect has been to restore to Egypt one of ber most fertile provinces which had been cut off from the rest of Egypt. The founders task has not altogether been an easy one. In the commencement we had many enemies and were laughed at and ridiculed by many fur proposing to build a railway heginning nowhere and ending nowhere. Standing here as | now do im the centre of a tract of country over 1,000 square miles in extent, of which a great part is caltivable land, | feel proud to be able to say that the construction of this railway has been fully justified and that | and my friends have beeo the weans of carrying out this great pu- blic work. We have now clearly demonstrated to you and the world the enormous tracts of veluable land which will vow be brought into cultivation, the abendance of the water supply and the sutheienncy of labour We can "aflord to torget the troubles and difhowlties we had to overcome in the past, to be generous and to forgive oar enemies. | have my reward in the satisfaction expressed

it, since the work it has taken in band will result in the additien of a new province to this country, the province of Western Egypt. Nature has eadowed the lands along the Nile from the annual over-flow of that river giving the land at once not only the requisite water, bat causing that water to carry with it the necessary fertiliser. Here we are far removed frou that river, yet natore has pro- vided for the irrigation and enrichment the soil. You have seen the abundant supply of beac- tifully pure artesian water projecting itself trom our boreholes to a sufficient height to enable the irrigation to be effected withoat re source to pumping, and turther that this water is ailed by avother nearer the surface which is available by the use of sakias. Nor has the means ot fertilisation been forgotten, for there are abundant deporits of phosphates and nitra- tes for this purpose. Already the trial crops which have been cultivated by us give promise of the most favoarableresults for those who may acqaire land from us and cultivate the same. The cotton we bave grown indicates that the best qualities may be prodeced here, and that the yield will probably not be leas than the average results attained in the Nille -Valley

It is, I think, a safe thingto prophesy now that a few decades will see large areas of this Oasis of Khargeh under cultivation, the population increasing Owing to the stoppageof the overflow which at present takes place to the Nile Valley and even the return of sume of that surplusage of past years to ils old home, 'whilat the rail
way wesaw opened yesterday will carry the products of the lands to markets where it can he profitably disposed of In Egypt it is usaa!
to place the caltivation of the land in the fore

most place, and rightly so, Lut in the Onses there are products which ofty prove equally as valuable as the land.) The investigations we have been consistently carrying on for some years past have shown us conclusively that there are amongst other things large quantities of material suitable tov the manufacture of high quality cement, for the manufacture of tilea, of pottery, of bricks, all of which the country requires for its own use There are also stones and building maternal of varied and excellent characteristics, and already we have carned out acoptract for the Government for the supply of stone for the pitching of some of the irrigation embankments, Further there are deposits of matenals of greater intrinsic value than tho-e | have just referred to such, asochres and alurns, and as time and opportunity serves the or)» ration will develope the uses of al! of these. We recognise to the fall the trust re posed inu= in the monopoly of railway com- munication between the Oasis and the Nile Valley, and we regard the first section of the railway opened yesterday as but the commence ment of the senes of communications which it will be our encleavour to continue in the fatare. The neighbouring Oasis of Dakhla mast at the earliest posable moment be provided with means of transp tt and that problem will receive our immediate attention The researches we have carried ont in that Oasis indicate that there are products of even greater value than those existing here, whilet the area of land already under cultivation and the larger popa-. lation combine to render it an objective of at least equal importance. After all, these matters to which | have drawn yoor attention, must be obviogs to you from the inspection which you have had the opportunity of making, and | need pot theretore further intnnge upon your time in deseribing them to you. | must again express our appreciation at the attendance
by your Excellency and for which | again | hereof so many distinguished gnests who will
tha k you. We feel that we have done our duty. Having ended I can only say | wish
Gud's speed to an enterpnse which must large

ly increase the revenoe of the country, do much good generally, and stand for ever as a monument of a public work carned ont for the good of this coantry Do not think that by wishing God speed to tbe Corporation that I
am severing my connection with it- On the
contrary | am making arrangements which willenable me in the future to devote more
time and attention to the Corporation whose interests | have so warmly at heart | am the

largest sbarebolder, | think [| have £50,000) | more im it than anyone else | hold more! shares now than | ever held and intention to stick to the ship so long as (iv! may be pleased to give me the health, strength, and business capacity to be of any service ty thie great ondertaking
At the conclusion of Mr. Heaton Armstrong « |
remarks, Mr. Manville, chairman ot the com pany, made the following speech —

First of all, on bebalf of the Corporation of Western Egypt Limited it gives me the greatest pleavure to welcome you al! here to day and to express the gratification of my colleagues and myself at the trouble and in convenience to whi®h you have put yourselves ip attending at the inauguration of this, the first stage in the development of what | think I may.safely term our peat undertaking His Excellency Fakbry Pasha hes been deputed by bis Highness the Khedive to declare the first section of our railway oper for the use of the public from to day and we are greatly gratified and honoured that his Highness bas thos ap preciated the national importance of the work we are engaged on, and to his Bxcellency himself | would express our warmest thanks for the generous and appreciative terms in which be has spoken of the work and prow pects of the Company. We consider that the work of the Corporation ie ope of great moment to this country, for whilet nature bas blessed it with perhaps the most productive soil im the world along the Nile Valley and the Delta yet the area of that land jis limited, and the pri vilege bas been a@onrded to us to add to the cultivable land the immense areas contained in this and the adjuining Oases The name ot the Company over which | have the honour at present to preside is, as you are aware, the Corporation of Western Egypt, and | doubt if a more apt name could have been found for

in the future te able to controvert these state ments which have been made, we hope in ignorance as to there being neither cultivable land nor Water witbin the areas covered by our concessions. In conelasion, | should like to ex press once again the appreciation of my colleagues and myself of the bonour his Ex cellency Fakhry Pasha has conferred apon os by formally opening the railway andl for the good wishes be has expressed for the prospent) of our vodertaking
Mr Maoville also made some engoliatic references to the manner in which the work of | construction had been earned out, Mr | Horublower respecding on behalf of the staff
The health of the cheirmnen was then pro
posed by General Bulk
having bnefly respor ol the proceedings | terminated
The afternoon wll loveted to further excursions in the Oasis «| the -necal train which is to convey the guests (o Kharge Junction will leave th: 'laste at [0 am. to
morrow morning
This evening a fantasiqg will be beld at the |
(basis by the natives of the district

div.head: BAEDEKER'S GUIDE TO EGYPT.
div.p: A new edition of Baedeker's "Egypt and the Sadan" has just been published, and will be of mach service to this country this season. The general information has been carefully sum- marised and brought up to date, and there is an interesting chapter on Egypt as a health resort, by De Leigh Canney, who gives man useful medical bints, which will be appreciated by the tourist visiting Egypt for the first time Captain Lyons and Dr. Schweinfurth contribute the Geographical and Political Notes, and Professor Georg Stheindorff, of Leipzig University, who has edited the German Handbook since 1897, and has supervised the preparation of the English editions, gives « concise outline of the history of Egypt asd the Egyptians There are also articles by Professor Stamme on the Arabic langoage, Franz Pasha on the buildings of the Moham medans, and Professor Socin oo the Doctrines of El-lslam. To the present edition have been added a new map of the environs of Assan, plans of Khartoum, and Omdurman, and many new ground plans !he maps and plans have al! been revised by Professor Steindorf

div.head: The Standard Life Assurance Company.
div.p: Established 1825.
Accumulated Funds £11,300,000
Bonus Year, 1905.
The next division of profits will be made amongst participating Policies in existence at 15th November 1905.
All With Profit Policies effected on or before that date will be entitled to share in the Division.
The Company have already declared Bonus Additions to Policies to the amount of more than Seven Million Sterling.
Head Office for Egypt: Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo.

div.head: BENGER'S Food
div.p: For Infants, Benger's Food solves the problem of hand-rearing. It contains all the elements necessary to healthy development in infancy.
For Invalids there is no food like Benger's Food. It assists nature in restoring the system to complete health.
For the Aged, Benger's Food is particularly adapted to the enfeebled digestion of advancing years.
For those who are well, Benger's Food is an ideal light meal, dainty and nutritive.
English and American Travellers can obtain supplies from or through
CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.- O. Guiliotti & Co.
CAIRO- Max Fisher. Walker & Meinarchi, Ltd.
The first essential for the preservation of the teeth is to keep them clean.
CALVERT'S Carbolic Tooth Powder
makes the use of your toothbrush so much more complete and satisfactory, because it perfects the cleansing, and also supplies the necessary antiseptic properties.
It is thoroughly pleasant to use, too, and leave a clean refreshing taste in the mouth.
F.C. CALVERT & Co., Manchester, Eng.

is delightful for bath and toilet use, and being antiseptic, alleviates the annoyance of prickly-heat or other skin irritation.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
